qas.question: Are there any purebreed lines for poultry today?

answers.text: with the exception of the white Leghorn, most commercial birds are of hybrid origin.

context: Since their domestication, a large number of breeds of chickens have been established, but <a0_0><b9_0>with the exception of the white Leghorn, most commercial birds are of hybrid origin<b9_0/>.<a0_0/> In about 1800, <b4_0>chickens began to be kept on a larger scale<b4_0/>, and <b5_0>modern high-output poultry farms<b5_0/> were present in the United Kingdom from around <b8_0>1920<b8_0/> and became established in the United States soon after the Second World War. <a1_0>By <b10_0>the mid-20th century<b10_0/>, the poultry meat-producing industry was of greater importance than <b6_0>the egg-laying industry<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Poultry breeding has produced breeds and strains to fulfil different needs; <a2_0><b11_0>light-framed, egg-laying birds that can produce <b7_0>300<b7_0/> eggs a year; fast-growing, fleshy birds destined for consumption<b11_0/><a2_0/> at a young age, and utility birds which produce both an acceptable number of eggs and a well-fleshed carcase. <b13_0>Male birds<b13_0/> are unwanted in the egg-laying industry and <a3_0>can often be identified as soon as they are hatch for subsequent culling<a3_0/>. In meat breeds, these birds are sometimes castrated (often chemically) to prevent aggression. The resulting bird, called a capon, <b12_0>has more tender and flavorful meat<b12_0/>, as well.
